title: Textile, "Iridescent Satin", ca. 1994–98
medium:
Medium: warp of polyester monofilament, weft of cotton
Technique: satin weave (4 + 1) and piece-dyed.  Iridescence is achieved by piece-dying as the blue dye adheres only to the polyester monofilament.
dimensions: Warp x Weft: 886.5 x 116.8 cm (29 ft. 1 in. x 46 in.)
creditline: Gift of The Museum of Modern Art, courtesy of the designer
description: Yardage of full manufactured width, yellowish orange cotton with blue iridescent highlights.
justification:
Koichi Yoshimura (b.1939) is a second generation textile designer educated at Kobe University.&nbsp; His company, S.Yoshimura, located in Fukui, an important textile manufacturing center in Japan, specializes in polyester and the combination of polyester with other yarns to create unusual effects.&nbsp; Besides his own creations, he has worked with fashion designers Issey Miyake, Yohji Yamamoto and Donna Karan.
Iridescent Satin, designed in 1994 by Yoshimura, combines polyester monofilament with a cotton weft, and through a piece-dyeing process in which the blue dye adheres only to the monofilament, Yoshimura achieves this intense blue highlight. His knowledge of the scientific properties of individual yarns as well as the dyeing process has transformed a relatively plain textile into a shimmering lighted surface. Thus, this textile reflects an understanding of not only current Japanese technology but also long-standing textile traditions in Japan.&nbsp;

tombstone.epitaph:
